title: ...why are you restricted from making custom rune pages until level 11
body:
actually though, why? I thought the rune update was to make runes available for anyone and everyone, but a restriction like that obviously bars new players from creating runes that are more viable for their current favorite champ.

It doesn't make much sense to me

replies.body: The reason is because new players literally have no idea what's going on 90% of the time. Riot wants them to focus on their gameplay rather than the additional things like runes and summoner spells. That's why they wait so long, because by level 17 they think "well maybe they can handle it". Otherwise, it's too overwhelming. This might not have been a problem in the beginning of league when many less champions were present, but now... I mean there's a lot to take in and learn.

This. Learning the game comes before learning the pregame, IMO.

All players have a full page of runes from level 1  and unlock customization as they level. The system is fully unlocked by level 17 so players have plenty of time to experiment with everything before 30.
Well it wouldn't be so bad if the preset runes were actually good.
Preset runes also need better names. Something like: mage/support/tank etc. so people get a general idea of what the runepage would do without having to actually read it.

Mm, worth noting that the point of the preset pages isn't to be the "best" options necessarily, just to be good general options that work on a wide range of champions interested in the path
That's a fair point.  I just mentioned precision because it seems like it was a spot on decision, specifically about the choices in the primary line.

I feel most of the complexity of the rune system comes more from learning what the runes do, rather than which runes are most appropriate. Even with locked options, new players are still going to have a very hard time understanding why their third attack deals massively more damage, what the progress bar is every time they step into brush, why they killed that slowed enemy so fast, and so on, if they take the Domination page, for example. Beyond that, champions are inevitably going to be balanced around their optimal rune builds, which means that newer players, who won't be able to have those even if they look up an online guide, will also be forced to play from a disadvantage. I don't think the current way the rune system is set up is as new player-friendly as it could be, for these reasons.
I thought the whole point of the new runes was to NOT gate them behind level gates and that's exactly what you have done.
No, the point (one of the points) was to not gate them behind a massive IP grind.

Nah, level gates were a bigpart of it. Not that either is entirely different from one another, but not having a Keystone until level 21, or a Quintessence until level 10 (which even then was sub-par) was really the worst of the issues that was addressed for newer players. They also dropped the level gate for a few Summoner Spells this past patch, with Runes Reforged.

Also, I've yet to hear anybody say the IP grind is any better. So even if both were goals, the level gate may be the only semi-success, as best I can tell.

Okay, but the presets are there and newcomers don't have to change them.

This is 100% only about pushing grind time and play hours.

There is no reason to not give more options. People who don't know won't explore different runes and will be fine with the presets. Anyone else, it creates massive upsets in balancing games. Since you can be placed with people a much higher level. For me it completely ruins the beginning of playing LoL.

I get the sentiment, but they have to learn this stuff somehow. You already have a plain English version of all the runes that's actually a bit overkill to anybody above level 10. Give them the tools, but don't shove it down their throat, or you'll lose people before they really invest into the game, especially players swapping from other games like DotA 2 and Smite. Preset pages are coddling enough for basically everybody at this point, they don't need to be mandatory.

Some of the problem is that you think new players expect no adjustment, I suppose. I don't think that anybody is expecting that on a new game. You guys have made Runes just about the hardest thing to mess up already, with basically all keystones coming with a helpful stat chunk based on that keystone, and 3 runes tailored to a similar playstyle. I think you're Diablo-3-ing the game, but regardless, new players should have little problem making their own pages that work, and this mandatory tutorial, when other players in the same games are not necessarily required to be in that tutorial anymore, is a problem in the game that should have been addressed many years ago. It has been addressed with Runes Reforged, but these little snags keep holding on, like not being able to create pages and being required to buy 6300 BE runepages for a 450 BE champion.

The problem is not that new players are getting confused on how to play and quitting. The problem is that new players are *still* being held back from their gameplay, and grow bored with the disadvantage thrown at them **in a team arena game**. I'd be ticked if I started with 300 gold while everyone else was at 500. Why? I still get the same endgame benefits and everything, right? 200 gold isn't much wait, right? No, it's a ton of wait when I'm playing a game with several other players who get that advantage, but I don't. That's the problem.

Please, stop choking players out from your game.

The preset Runes are horrible though..... Doesn't teach them anything good in fact it leads them to think those rune pages are good when they are not. At least look into the most popular Rune builds and remake the Premade Rune Pages accordingly so that new players are not mislead with bad Rune pages.
Yeah, people forget how overwhelming League can be to new players, especially those new to the concept of MOBAs in general.

league is at this point, one of the easiest-to-understand moba's. there are plenty out there which have stunning graphic and gameplay and are way better. 

why do most trolls come to league? cause they dont need to bother upgrading their pc, just buy a crappy one and get windows xp running to play league. hots requires you to have atleast windows 7 or better(as they locked out every xp/vista user from playing in november)

Problem is, you need to address new players appropriately for the genre you are in. As an example, you may start with learning basic exercises, leg stretches and such, when swapping from Bowling to Soccer. However, catering to those 3 people with no route around those basic concepts will bore people who came from more similar games, which actually require the same endurance to play, like your Football, Basketball, Hockey, etc.

That's not to say that the basic exercise tutorials shouldn't exist. But for crying out loud, there just aren't that many Bowlers trying to play Soccer. Leave some room for players who already know the basics, especially when the help suggested isn't even that helpful to incredibly new players. If you're *that* new, you'll pick a preset. Nobody that new is going to go off and do his own exercises knowing his inherent disadvantages. However, your MOBA peeps, or even general MMORPG peeps, should not be hit hard enough to be confused at the thought of a Runepage setup. Not with as basic a setup they've been confined to.

I know that there are a couple players who can really use some extra help. My girlfriend was one of those, and I used to semi-coach a few back in the day (gf being one). However, I don't think I've seen anybody that flat-out ignored presets if they were that new to the game. If anything, they sought out such help, because the choices were overwhelming early.

The help is there. Just don't force it on **everybody**, or you'll lose players much easier. This game really isn't that hard to adjust to, as long as they point to the tutorials. Once those tutorials were in place, even new players on the "noob" channel back in the day were generally knowledgeable of the game by the time they sought help, they were simply looking for community, or nowadays, considered to be looking for boosting. It's all a fine line, but as a general rule, don't tell people how to play unless they ask. Advice is good, but forcing is next to always bad.

Okay let me say this. When you are first learning the game, a MOBA veteran or not, do you know exactly how each champions stats work? Armour? Magic resist? AP scaling? AD scaling? Which champions can build which paths? Which can build both paths? How exactly to lane in league? When to use e? w? q? r? The point is to give people a little bit of time to figure out what they need to do. It doesn't take that long to get to level 17. It really doesn't. For returning players, it's a struggle to not be able to use your runes when you know what they do, but it's also a way to deter extra smurfs and alternate accounts. For people from a different moba, no matter how similar it is, there are also many differences. Riot just wants you to focus on the big picture rather than the little stuff in the beginning. Learn specific champs and how to build them and THEN focus on which runes may fit your playstyle. Arguably, even people from other mobas might not know which playstyle they prefer in THIS game. So riot is making it so they focus on other things first before they dive into the other stuff. That's why. Yes, people that have played other sports might know how to stretch, but maybe they dont' know the specific exercises they should do before starting a different sport. It's kinda the same thing ya know?

Knowing the enemy playstyle is a necessary evil. No way around it, because it's been fine-tuned for years. However, knowing how your champion interacts with Summon Aery, as an example, is not hard to figure out after one game, if you even need that game. They are very basic already, and don't need a 3-week tutorial to cover before you can even consider trying that OP Annie build you just saw last game, because you had the misfortune of facing one who passed the tutorial.

Even excluding all of that, there is little to no reason to hold back players who do not seek the help. As a universal example, you teach players in Chess how to do things, correct movement, en passant, how to castle, etc. However, that doesn't make it helpful to restrict a player from castling when the opponent gets to. If you want to intertwine players of different skill levels, they're going to need the same skills, or else you're setting up the new player for a bad experience, especially when they can't adjust to mimic that playstyle the following game.

Again, advice is good. Presets are good. Forcing is bad. When I am playing League of Legends, I expect to be playing the full game, just like everyone else. If I'm playing League of Legends Junior in a full-on LoL match, I'm probably going to get frustrated simply because I can't do the fun things I just saw some guy do. If I'm a relatively adjusted player due to playing a similar game (DotA 2, HoN, Smite), I'm gonna drop that game in heartbeat. That's just not fun for anybody.

Again, I used to coach these peeps. They were never that helpless to learn the game back in the day, and this was before the better tutorial came out. However, that could be for a variety of reasons. Many could be because even the movement tutorial was too hard/unfun for them. However, I promise you that forcing preset pages, as opposed to suggesting them, was not going to bring those folks back. They used those presets to a fault already, at least those that were willing to learn. The rest were frustrated with the appearance of a prescribed tutorial, and quit ahead of time.

There is literally no benefit to having a forced 10-level tutorial. Players that want to shove a playstyle can't experiment. Players who want to stay the course end up stomped by those that don't, and then can't adapt to it. It is backwards of Riot's main (and viable) philosophy, learn by playing. If you can't play that way, how do they expect you to learn about dealing with it? Keep in mind, there are 10 of 15 keystones that are unobtainable until level 10. That's a lot of coddling, and ultimately, no benefit.

But this is how it's been for years. Except for before you didn't even get to have runes. You literally had... 7 runes at level 7 you could use, that was IF you decided to purchase them (before they made everyone 1ip for tier 2 runes). This time, they gave you the option to use full runepages, but won't let you edit them at first. I fail to see how much different it is. The first 30 levels are to show you how to play the game and get you prepared for level 30 (which is where the game really "starts" imo). There are several games where you get a full first few level tutorial. WoW, GW2, other games like that all have basically the same starting sequence of 'teach you how to do this' and then they give you stuff to explore on your own. I'm confused as to why you think league should be different? Riot _could_ implement a system where if you were already level 30 and were creating a smurf you could opt in to a "veteran" status where it skips the tutorial, but then it doesn't really make the game fair to everyone, and then also people will abuse this and then never learn the game properly (or use it to harass new members). I mean, riot is trying to help NEW people, not necessarily hinder their progress, but it's like trying to teach a white belt a black belt move. You know? And you can argue that people don't WANT the help, but that's just how this game progresses it's starting players. I'd be pissed if I was trying to learn this game and got ZERO help.

Of course it sucked before. That doesn't mean it's peachy now. They've been one of the worst game introductions in big games because they created these "milestones" in the name of learning the game, and kept scaring off their playerbase, which was okay with a fresh game. Now, 7 years in, they finally get rid of their largest barrier, and they go and put some new ones up for the hell of it.

There is literally no benefit to forcing presets. Having presets is good, forcing them is bad. It's tolerable for a few tutorial games, but not 10 levels. New players get the benefit from having the presets, but the veteran gamers play for accolades, not access to a repetitive game. And overall, that's likely the majority of incoming players in the first place.

Again, presets good. Forcing bad. Forcing presets helps nobody, old or new. Nobody is advocating zero help. Nobody is taking away the tutorials, or recommended item sets, or even preset runes. It's all about allowing game access if the player wants to actually use runes to a realistic degree. If this were an MMORPG, maybe let the player gain some power over time, let them come into their own. However, not in a game entirely based on PVP. You force a player to play with their hands tied behind their back, they'll go somewhere else. That has been their problem for a few seasons now, and Riot can't seem to work their way past it, despite this update being tailored toward it.

Is Riot doing better with new players? Probably. I personally think that they've devolved the game so badly that the newer player experience is not enhanced. However, no matter the case, that doesn't make this particular issue any more sparkly. Give players presets, but don't 100% force it on them. That's where there is a problem.
Believe it or not, Rito actually wants to attract new players and not just cater to Smurfs :/
